tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: Grab your small shield and large shield ... your spear and battle ax
tn.text: These phrases describe God as a warrior who is preparing himself for battle. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
these are defensive weapons
these are offensive weapons
Possible meanings are 1) these enemies are literally chasing the writer or 2) this is a metaphor for people who are enemies of the writer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the writer. AT: "say to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be stated without the abstract noun. AT: "I am your savior" or "I will save you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: May those who seek my life be shamed and dishonored
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May Yahweh shame and dishonor those who seek my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"I wish that"
Here "seek my life" means they desire to kill the writer. AT: "who are trying to kill me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: May those who plan to harm me be turned back and confounded
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May Yahweh turn back and confound those who plan to harm me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"be turned back" is a metaphor for being unable to accomplish their goal. AT: "be unsuccessful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"confused" or "perplexed"
The writer's enemies are spoken of as if they are chaff that is easily blown away. AT: "blown away by the wind like chaff" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here "their way" refers to their lives. AT: "their lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to a way that is hidden and dangerous. AT: "hidden and full of dangers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the angel of Yahweh being opposed to the writer's enemies. AT: "works against them" or "opposes them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they set their net for me
tn.text: The schemes of the wicked are spoken of as if they were a net that they set to catch the writer. AT: "they want to catch me in a net like a small animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they dug a pit for my life
tn.text: The schemes of the wicked are spoken of as if they were a pit that they dug to catch the writer. AT: "they wanted to capture me in a pit like a big animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the writer. AT: "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Let destruction overtake them by surprise
tn.text: Destruction is spoken of as if it was a dangerous animal that would suddenly attack them. AT: "Let them be destroyed suddenly" or "Let them be surprised because you destroy them suddenly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: the net that they have set
tn.text: The schemes of the wicked are spoken of as if they were a net that they place to catch the writer. AT: "the net that they placed  in order to capture me like an animal and harm me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This is the same metaphor as in verse 7. The net is intended to catch the writer. AT: "Let them fall into the pit that they dug for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Possible meanings are 1) fall into the pit of verse 7 or 2) fall into destruction.
The abstract noun "destruction" can be stated in other forms. AT: "so that they will be destroyed" or "that is how you should destroy them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as a verb. AT: "because you save me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "bones" refers to the deepest inner being of a person. AT: "My whole inner being" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Yahweh, who is like you ... those who try to rob them?
tn.text: The implicit answer to this question is that no one is like Yahweh. AT: "Yahweh, there is no one like you ... those who try to rob them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The words "poor" and "needy" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh saves many who need his help. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This means they testify in a trial. AT: "volunteer to give a testimony" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: They repay me evil for good
tn.text: This is a metaphor which means they give back evil in exchange for the good they have received.  AT: "In return for my doing good things for them, they do evil things to me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These abstract nouns can be stated in other forms. AT: "evil things ... good things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"I am extremely sad"
The word "they" refers to the "unrighteous witnesses" ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:035:011|35:11]]).
"I showed that I was sad" (UDB)

tn.ref: with my head bowed on my chest
tn.text: This was a symbol of prayer. "with my head bent down in prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: in grief as for my brother
tn.text: The writer was as sad as if his own brother had died. AT: "grieving as if my own brother was ill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: I bent down in mourning as for my mother
tn.text: The writer mourned as if his own mother had died. AT: "I mourned as if my own mother had died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This was a symbol of pain and suffering. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"assembled together" or "came together"
This means they came together for the purpose of attacking the writer. AT: "to make plans against me" or "to plan my destruction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the treated the writer as if he were a piece of cloth that they could tear to pieces. AT: "They attacked me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: With no respect at all they mocked me
tn.text: "With the worthless people they ridiculed me" or 2) "Without respect they made fun of me"

tn.ref: they gnashed at me with their teeth
tn.text: This is a sign of anger and hate. "they made grinding noises with their teeth at me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: how long will you look on?
tn.text: This rhetorical question indicates that the writer wants God to stop simply looking on and to start to help him. AT: "how long will you only watch them doing this" (UDB) or "when will you help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "soul" refers to the writer. AT: "Rescue me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "save" is implied. AT: "save my life from the lions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This refers to the writer. AT: "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the writer speaks of his enemies as if they were vicious lions. AT: "from my enemies who attack me like wild animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not let my deceitful enemies
tn.text: "Do not let my enemies, who tell lies about me,"
"their evil plans"
The abstract noun "peace" can be stated in other forms. AT: "they do not speak peacefully to people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"look for ways to tell lies" (UDB)

tn.ref: those in our land who live in peace
tn.text: "those who live peacefully in our land"
The abstract noun "peace" can be stated in other forms. AT: "do no harm to anyone" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: They open their mouths wide against me
tn.text: The reason they open their mouths is to accuse the writer. AT: "They shout at me in order to accuse me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is an exclamation that is used when something is suddenly seen or understood. It emphasizes the statement that follows. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

Here "our eyes" refers to the enemies' eyes. It is implied that they are saying they saw the writer do something wrong. AT: "we have seen it" or "we saw the wrong things that you did" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "it" refers to the false accusations of the writer's enemies. AT: "You have seen how they falsely accused me"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"do not ignore what they did" This can be stated in positive form. AT: "judge them because of what they did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: do not be far from me
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "be very close to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

This does not mean that God is actually asleep. The writer wants God to intervene. Both words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the urgency of this request. AT: "I feel like you are sleeping! Wake up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This abstract noun can be stated in another form. AT: "to defend me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This refers to the writer. AT: "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: do not let them rejoice over me
tn.text: "do not let them be glad because I am suffering"
This is an idiom that means to say to oneself. AT: "say to themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an exclamation that is used when something is suddenly seen or understood. It emphasizes what follows. AT: "Yes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
It is implied that the writer's enemies wanted him to be declared guilty. AT: "he has been declared guilty just as we desired!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The writer's enemies speak of his destruction as if they were wild animals who had eaten him. AT: "We have swallowed him up" or "We have destroyed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"humiliate" or "perplex"

tn.ref: May those who taunt me be covered with shame and dishonor
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May you cover with shame and dishonor those who taunt me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
to insult someone to make them angry

Here shame and dishonor are spoken of as if they were shameful clothes that the writer could wear. These abstract nouns can be stated as verbs. AT: "shamed and dishonored" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These terms mean about the same thing and are used to emphasize how degraded they will be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here "vindication" refers to Yahweh proclaiming or judging the psalmist innocent.
"may they always say"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Let us praise Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"who is happy with" or "who is glad for"
well-being, happiness
The abstract noun "justice" can be stated with a verb. AT: "proclaim that you act in the right way" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
